## Meeting Notes

### Technical Architecture & Security Discussion

- Brian Corbin introduction: Principal Engineer for AI Orchestration zone
  - Covers agents, chatbots, knowledge AI by AutomateFlow
  - Works with AutomateFlow MCP team on system alignment
- Hakan requests access to AutomateFlow architecture documentation
  - GitLab repo with system architecture diagrams used for SOC2 audits
  - High-level and system-level views available
  - Brian to provide access link via TeamChat

### Current System & AI Implementation Plans

- Hakan’s background: Head of Legal & Compliance at NetPro Solutions (Turkish company)
  - In-house lawyer in Berlin, learned AI/automation independently
  - Built complex AutomateFlow workflows replacing previous macro systems
- Current workflow structure:
  - Software connects to UYAP (Turkish enforcement file database)
  - Data flows: UYAP → gathering software → AutomateFlow → TaskBoard
  - Processing enforcement files for debt collection via bailment offices
- Exceeded task limits, planning upgrade to 60,000 plan
- AI agent implementation ideas:
  - Process legal documents (expert reports) for meaningful insights
  - “Clone yourself as agent” to analyze documents stating rights/obligations
  - Feed processed insights into TaskBoard via AutomateFlow
- TaskBoard’s agent offering tested but found insufficient technical capabilities

### Security & Enterprise Considerations

- Security requirements for confidential legal documents
- Agent infrastructure uses same security as standard AutomateFlow workflows
- LLM processing through Anthropic models (direct + AWS Bedrock)
- No training on customer data - explicit agreements with third parties
- Current pricing structure:
  - Teams plan includes \~100 agent actions with add-on options
  - Enterprise plans include \~30,000 agent actions built-in
- Enterprise discussion potential:
  - Engin (Head of AI Transformation) expressed interest after Alex’s outreach
  - Hakan becoming internal AutomateFlow ambassador, other teams replicating his work
  - Next step: Hakan to discuss enterprise options with Engin before scheduling follow-up

### Next Steps

- Brian: Send architecture documentation access link
- Hakan: Upgrade to higher task limit plan
- Hakan: Discuss enterprise partnership with Engin internally
- Alex: Follow-up email with meeting summary and calendar availability
- Potential future meeting with Engin and AI transformation team

activityLog.description: Sent first follow-up to Hakan. **Good news: Hakan upgraded to 60K plan (~$1K revenue increase)** - demonstrates follow-through and continued investment. Still need to get intro to Engin scheduled. James follow up again to push for the Engin meeting.
Initial research and outreach strategy developed. Identified Hakan as power user, Engin/Cafer/Kerem as expansion targets.
Sent intro email to Hakan acknowledging his sophisticated automation work, flagging renewal and AI capabilities.
Hakan responded - interested in Agents but has security concerns about legal data. Booked meeting.
Requested SA/TAM support for security conversation. Brian Corbin (Principal Engineer) joined.

**Discovery call with Hakan and Brian Corbin.** Key outcomes: Brian explained Agents security architecture - Anthropic models, no training on customer data, same security as core AutomateFlow Hakan satisfied with security explanation ("no training for AI means it's more secure") Hakan disclosed he's upgrading to 60K plan due to exceeded limits Major revelation: Engin (Head of AI Transformation) already engaged after Alex's outreach - "Hakan, what are you doing there?" Other teams starting to replicate Hakan's work Hakan becoming internal AutomateFlow ambassador Next step: Hakan to discuss enterprise with Engin, then coordinate follow-up meeting Brian to send architecture docs

doc_netpro-solutions_hakan-followup-2026.title: hakan-followup-2026-01-21
doc_netpro-solutions_hakan-followup-2026.content:
Subject: Great connecting today - next steps on AutomateFlow + Agents



Hakan,

Thanks for making time today, and for walking us through what you've built. The legal case management system you've created is genuinely impressive - the complexity of those workflows (68 steps with branching logic) is something we typically only see from dedicated automation engineers.

What we covered:

Brian confirmed the security architecture for Agents: data transits the same way as standard Zaps, LLM processing runs through Anthropic (with AWS Bedrock), and we have explicit agreements with subprocessors that no customer data is used for training

One follow-up on data usage: You can also opt out of AutomateFlow using your data for AI model training on your current plan - just fill out the opt-out form at AutomateFlow.com/security-compliance. Enterprise plans auto-opt out all users, which may be relevant to the Engin conversation.

Your plan to move Excel macro logic into Agents makes sense for stability - the current spikes in your usage are likely tied to macro retry behavior

You're upgrading to the 50K plan to accommodate current growth

Next steps:

Brian James send over the architecture documentation via TeamChat

You James connect with Engin to discuss whether an enterprise partnership makes sense for NetPro Solutions

We can schedule a follow-up with you, Engin, and whoever else should be involved once you've had that conversation

On enterprise partnership:

Two things that might be relevant as you talk to Engin:

For you specifically - enterprise plans include ~30,000 agent actions built in (vs. the 100 on Teams with add-ons). If you're serious about using Agents for document analysis, that headroom matters. We'd also help bring your colleagues up to speed so you're not the only one who knows how to build and maintain these workflows.

For Engin and the AI transformation initiative - we work with companies globally on making AI an operational lever, not just a productivity tool for drafting emails. The difference between "everyone has ChatGPT access" and "AI is embedded in how we actually run the business" is significant, and it's the work Engin seems to be driving. Happy to share what we're seeing work.

Let me know how the conversation with Engin goes - I'll hold time flexible for a follow-up.

Alex

doc_netpro-solutions_pronet-deal-channel.title: NetPro Solutions-deal-channel-brief
doc_netpro-solutions_pronet-deal-channel.content:
NetPro Solutions Security Services - Enterprise Expansion (Legal → Company-wide)

Turkey's largest electronic security company. Land-and-expand opportunity—Head of Legal built sophisticated automation on Pro plan, is now internal AutomateFlow ambassador. Head of AI Transformation (Engin) is engaged and pushing other teams to replicate. Path from $3.4K ARR to enterprise.

SalesCloud Deal: https://example.com/...

Gong Call (Jan 21): https://example.com/...

What do they do?

NetPro Solutions is Turkey's leading electronic security provider (founded 1995)

~200K subscribers, 1-5K employees

24/7 alarm monitoring, camera services, residential and commercial security

PE-backed (Cinven/Turkven) - had major exit in 2019

Serves major banks and retail chains

Contacts

Hakan Madi - Director, Legal & Compliance. Champion. Based in Berlin, built entire legal case management system on AutomateFlow (1.4M tasks/year, 68-step workflows). Self-described "ambassador inside the corporation." Upgrading to 50K plan. Interested in Agents for legal document processing.

Engin Kurtay - CCO / Head of AI Transformation. Likely economic buyer. 23 years at NetPro Solutions, manages 500 employees + 150 subcontractors. Already engaged—saw my outreach and asked Hakan "what are you doing there?" Now pushing other teams to replicate Hakan's work. Harvard Business School background.

Brian Corbin (AutomateFlow) - Principal Engineer, AI Orchestration. Joined discovery call to address Agents security questions. Sending architecture docs to Hakan.

What they're trying to solve

Current (Hakan/Legal):

Legal case management for debt collection/enforcement files

Data flows from UYAP (Turkish enforcement database) → gathering software → AutomateFlow → TaskBoard

Replaced unstable Excel macros with AutomateFlow workflows

Pain: Usage spikes from macro retry behavior causing billing unpredictability

Next (Hakan wants Agents for):

Process legal documents (expert reports) for insights

Extract rights/obligations from documents automatically

"Clone myself as an agent" to analyze documents and feed insights to TaskBoard

Tested TaskBoard's agents, found them technically insufficient

Broader (Engin's AI transformation):

Company-wide automation adoption (CX, operations, technical services)

FlowBuilder AI an operational lever, not just productivity tool

Unknown specific use cases yet—need discovery with Engin

Current state

Plan: Pro 20K monthly → upgrading to 50K

ARR: $10-20K

Users: 1 (Hakan only)

Tasks/month: 142K total, 33K billable

Active Zaps: 39

Renewal: 7 days

Tech stack: TaskBoard (primary database), Excel, AutomateFlow Tables, Google Sheets, UYAP integration

AI usage: Light - 6,796 AI by AutomateFlow tasks/year, minimal ChatGPT

What they care about

Security/data isolation - Legal data is confidential. Brian addressed on call, Hakan satisfied. Flagged opt-out form for additional protection.

Agents capability - Wants to process legal documents with AI. Current Teams plan has limited agent actions (100), enterprise has 30K.

Independence from IT - Hakan explicitly doesn't want to "depend on some IT guys." Prefers agility of running his own automation.

Broader adoption - Engin pushing other teams to replicate Hakan's work.

Deal sizing

Current: $10-20K ARR (Pro 20K monthly) → $5K+ (Pro 50K)

Enterprise opportunity: $50K+ ARR

Platform with agent actions (30K vs 100 on Teams)

TAM support for broader rollout

Training/enablement for other teams

SSO/SCIM for IT governance (if Engin brings IT in)

Expand path:

CX team (Engin manages 500 employees in customer ops)

Technical services / field operations

Call center automation

Consolidation play if other teams adopt

Timeline

Nov 26 - Initial research, identified expansion opportunity

Nov 27 - Intro email to Hakan

Dec 16 - Hakan responded, interested in Agents, security concerns

Jan 21 - Discovery call with Hakan + Brian Corbin (today)

Next - Hakan talks to Engin internally about enterprise

TBD - Follow-up meeting with Engin and AI transformation team

Competitive situation

TaskBoard Agents - Tested and rejected. "Great UI, doesn't work technically." No threat.

Status quo - Main competitor. Hakan values his independence and agility. May resist formalized enterprise deal if it means IT involvement.

Our angle: Hakan is already winning internally. We're not displacing anything—we're scaling what's already proven. Enterprise unlocks agent capacity he needs and gives Engin governance/visibility he wants.

Risk assessment

Hakan prefers independence over enterprise deal → Frame enterprise as enabling his work, not constraining it. Agent capacity is the hook.

IT involvement slows things down → Hakan is trying to avoid this. May need to position carefully with Engin.

Engin conversation doesn't materialize → Hakan is motivated to have it—Agents capacity is gated on it.

Turkish company / procurement complexity → Unknown. PE-backed suggests process exists.

Why we win this

Internal champion is doing the selling - Hakan is literally becoming their AutomateFlow ambassador without us asking

Proof of value exists - 1.4M tasks, mission-critical legal workflows, already replaced competitor (Excel macros)

Executive air cover - Engin is engaged and pushing adoption before we've even talked to him

Clear upgrade driver - Agent capacity. Hakan wants it, current plan doesn't have enough.

No real competition - TaskBoard agents failed, IntegrateHub/FlowBuilder not in picture

Resources needed

If Engin meeting happens:

Executive sponsor connection - Engin is CCO with Harvard background, 23 years at company. May warrant exec alignment on our side.

SA support for broader discovery - What are CX/ops use cases? What's the automation potential across 500 employees?

Not needed yet:

No immediate asks - still early stage

Hakan is handling internal socialization

Next steps

Send Hakan follow-up email (done - sending today)

Brian sends architecture docs to Hakan

Hakan discusses enterprise with Engin

Hakan confirms if IT needs to be involved

Schedule follow-up with Engin + relevant stakeholders

Bottom line

Low-effort, high-potential expansion. Champion is doing internal selling, executive is already engaged, usage is growing. No urgent action needed—just need to be ready when Engin conversation happens. If that lands, James want to think about exec alignment given Engin's seniority (CCO, 23 years, Harvard).

doc_netpro-solutions_hakan-followup.title: hakan-followup

groundTruth.whatHappenedNext: Requested SA/TAM support for security conversation. Brian Corbin (Principal Engineer) joined.. **Discovery call with Hakan and Brian Corbin.** Key outcomes: Brian explained Agents security architecture - Anthropic models, no training on customer data, same security as core AutomateFlow Hakan satisfied with security explanation ("no training for AI means it's more secure") Hakan disclosed he's upgrading to 60K plan due to exceeded limits Major revelation: Engin (Head of AI Transformation) already engaged after Alex's outreach - "Hakan, what are you doing there?" Other teams starting to replicate Hakan's work Hakan becoming internal AutomateFlow ambassador Next step: Hakan to discuss enterprise with Engin, then coordinate follow-up meeting Brian to send architecture docs

Sent first follow-up to Hakan. **Good news: Hakan upgraded to 60K plan (~$1K revenue increase)** - demonstrates follow-through and continued investment. Still need to get intro to Engin scheduled. James follow up again to push for the Engin meeting.
